{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3356215,"name":"Rohan","username":"rohanMoment","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/439d5e/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-04-09T13:32:50.015Z","cooked":"

Hi!
I am planning out an autonomous that goes to the center line for a note. However, what I want it to do is skip the return path if the note is not there. For example if the amp-side note is not present, then the return path should be skipped and instead should rotate and attack the next note over on the center line. However, I am struggling on how to write the code for this… any help would be appreciated!

Thanks,
6147

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2024-04-09T13:32:50.015Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":267,"reads":340,"readers_count":339,"score":1418.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":461911,"topic_slug":"contingency-based-pathplanner-autonomous","display_username":"Rohan","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":55904,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/contingency-based-pathplanner-autonomous/461911/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true,"can_vote":false},{"id":3356220,"name":"Tyson Whelan","username":"Tyson453","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/t/e56c9b/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-04-09T13:40:26.091Z","cooked":"

My team hasn’t implemented this but when I first saw teams doing it, my first thought was ConditionalCommands. Something like this:

new ConditionalCommand(
  new PickupAndDriveBack(), // Command to run if condition is true - pickup the note you see then drive back and shoot
  new DriveToNextNote(), // Command to run if condition is false - drive to next note
  () -> camera.seesNote() // Condition - Check if the camera can see the note
)

If you provide an example of one of your current auto commands, I may be able to provide a more constructive answer.

If you are using command-based, you can use a ConditionalCommand to accomplish this: ConditionalCommand (WPILib API 2024.3.2)

We kind of do this idea in our Path planner auto.

We use PathPlanner’s built in race groups when we drive to intake notes. We have our drive path and intake command in a race group, so if the intake command ends (it ends when a note is in the shooter) the robot will stop driving the path it is on and go to shoot.

So in your case, you could have you drive to shoot spot in a race group with a command that ends if a note is not in your robot. Though I’m not sure how well it would drive to the next note after skipping your paths, so you might need to still explore ConditionalCommands like others have suggested. (But race groups still might help with some parts of implementing this)

I was trying to put together an example but you beat me to it! @rohanMoment one challenge with this approach is getting the timing of the decision right. It may be the case that the moment “seesNote()” is called you don’t see the note, even though you saw it moments before or may see it a moment later.

@rohanMoment We were actually developing something similar - I’d recommend checking out our most recent Open Alliance post.

FRC 1257 Parallel Universe |2024 Build Thread | Open Alliance Open Alliance
Hi! Hope you’re having a nice day! DCMP Prep We’ve mainly been focusing on how best to improve our robot before we leave it for spring break. Our biggest focuses were: Everything Functioning Mechanically Vision Aligners Autos It was crunch time for us, and being the team with the lowest EPA going into DCMP, it was cook or be cooked for us. Just in case, we’ve also been developing the Snail Sail which is basically a blocker that goes on the intake side of our robot. Driver Practice We ran fu…
","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2024-04-09T15:27:29.196Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":205,"readers_count":204,"score":71.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":461911,"topic_slug":"contingency-based-pathplanner-autonomous","display_username":"Sam Beilis","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/frc-1257-parallel-universe-2024-build-thread-open-alliance/447080/25","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"FRC 1257 Parallel Universe |2024 Build Thread | Open Alliance","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57688,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/contingency-based-pathplanner-autonomous/461911/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3356952,"name":"Akash Dubey | Programming Captain 1257","username":"AkeBoss","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/akeboss/{size}/203787_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-09T22:49:27.451Z","cooked":"

Yeah, take a look at our stuff. In order to properly drive a full auto like that, it’s important to have good pose estimation (using april tags and odometry) so the robot always knows where it is on the field.

Once you drive up to where you want to use vision to see the note, you can run a command that will take control of driving and try to gobble up the note. This command should stop once it has a note and afterward trigger a sequence to go to the next note.

If you’re using Path Planner, the easiest way we’ve found to go to where we want to score it is to use the built in path finding functionality. You could also create trajectories on the fly but this has a chance of hitting obstacles on the field. Some teams already use this to, for example, align with the amp. Here’s a demo

Since our robot was making these autos on the fly, we needed some way to tell the robot which notes to pick up. So, we created a position chooser that we used to create the drive to pose commands.

Then for the logic (contingencies) for these autos, we used all our commands and added onlyIf to only do things if certain conditions were true.

Here’s the code I’m talking about

image1042×449 19.3 KB

We don’t have note vision yet, but theoretically you could add one once the robot has driven to where it thinks a note is and then once it gets it, you could go to score. In our custom autos, the robot checks to see if it has a note before driving back to score.

Here’s an example of when the robot thinks it doesn’t have a note and moves on to the next note in the auto.

This is kind of unrelated, but another cool thing you can do is limit how the path finder makes paths with dynamic obstacles which are demonstrated here

That’s all we’ve developed so far, but you can definitely take it further with note vision.
